<target_code>
Here is the code of mutex_thread:
```c
static void *mutex_thread(void *arg)
{
	metal_mutex_t *l = arg;
	int i;

	for (i = 0; i < mutex_test_count; i++) {
		metal_mutex_acquire(l);
		usleep(1);
		metal_mutex_release(l);
	}

	return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other fragments do not need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 because they do not introduce pointer-to-object types whose pointee const-qualification could/should be assessed. The loop index declaration (int i;) and the for-loop control are ordinary non-pointer objects. The calls to metal_mutex_acquire(l) and metal_mutex_release(l) pass the pointer to functions that presumably operate on and modify the mutex object; these calls themselves do not indicate a missing const qualification on the pointee. The usleep(1) call and the return NULL; statement do not involve pointer-to-object types relevant to the rule. Therefore only the pointer parameter and its assignment to a pointer variable are flagged for investigation.
